description: From Middle English fromward, framward, from Old English framweard (“about to depart, departing, doomed to die; with his back turned”, adjective) and framweardes (“away from”, adverb), equivalent to from +‎ -ward. Compare froward.

adjectives.description: fromward (comparative more fromward, superlative most fromward)

entries.meaning: (now dialect, Southern England, Midlands, West Country) Leaning or listing away from; distant from; on the right-hand side; on the opposite side.

adverbs.description: fromward (comparative more fromward, superlative most fromward)

entries.meaning: (now dialect, Southern England, Midlands, West Country) Forth; forward.
(now dialect, Southern England, Midlands, West Country) A cleaving tool; an iron instrument with a blade set at right angles on a short handle, used for splitting laths or rails.
(now dialect, Southern England, Midlands, West Country) From; away from.
